Award.AwardTitle: Developing and Assessing Engineering Students' Cognitive Flexibility in the Domain of Sustainable Design

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration: Due to global trends in rising resource consumption and environmental degradation, numerous professional organizations like the National Academy of Engineering and the National Society of Professional Engineers have called on the engineering profession to address sustainable development in their projects and decision-making. For engineers to effectively contribute to global sustainable development, they must learn to understand and apply sustainability concepts in problem-solving and design. Typically in design classes, undergraduate students have difficulty integrating or building on knowledge from other engineering and non-engineering courses to evaluate the broader context for their decision-making. Therefore, the goal of this project is to develop and assess a sustainable design framework for instruction in upper-level design courses that develops students' ability to apply complex knowledge across different problem contexts. As potentially cross-cutting features of engineering curricula, "design" and "sustainability" represent an opportunity for integration and development of a unifying thread for engineering problem-solving.<br/><br/>The proposed research uses a novel application of cognitive flexibility theory to the complex and ill-structured domain of sustainable engineering design, intended to prepare students for solving societal challenges of sustainable development. The project team seeks a better understanding of how students learn and how they use and transfer knowledge of sustainable design thinking, tools, and processes in new settings. Of particular importance is how these experiences help to make better engineers and could lead to better outcomes for all career destinations. The team will employ a mixed-methods approach to measure the depth and breadth of such learning. Guided by four research questions, it is anticipated that: (a) classification of real-world sustainable design problems will lead to an understanding and characterizing of complex problem solving domains and processes, (b) students' learning outcomes (cognitive, affective, social, and professional) will be assessed in order to understand how these problems enable cognitive abilities, (c) innovative instruments and assessment tools, that can be transferred across institutions, programs, departments, and experiences, will be developed, and (d) strategies for implementing complex sustainable design problem solving in engineering education will be investigated. Through this project a broad community of practice of engineering educators will be established across disciplines, as design instruction is incorporated into all accredited engineering programs and as the challenge of sustainable development is a call to all engineers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Real-world engineering challenges are open-ended, complex, and exist within a societal context. Tackling those types of challenges requires knowledge from multiple areas (e.g., technical, environmental, economic, legal, social). Students gain knowledge in each of those areas from a variety of undergraduate classes and informal learning experiences, both engineering and non-engineering. However, most engineering students have difficulty integrating all of that knowledge when they are faced with new, complex problems. The goal of this project was to investigate different approaches for helping students develop more connections between the different knowledge areas. We also wanted students to learn how to draw upon what they're learning to improve their design projects. As part of the research, students completed different learning activities as individuals and on teams, and the researchers studied how those activities impacted students' understanding of different design challenges. For example, when facing an issue with food availability, what should engineers keep in mind and how can they creatively use technology to address the problem?

Results showed that creating concept maps can help engineering students make new connections between what they're learning and real-world problems. Essentially, concept mapping may help the brain organize new information and experiences so that the information can be applied to new problems. The research also showed that simple but well-constructed learning tools like rubrics can help students consider new aspects of their design problems and solutions, especially when they are working on teams. In addition to using the concept maps and rubrics, this project also tested the use of neurological measures (e.g., brain waves) to understand how students respond to complex problems.

The project has led to new learning tools that can be used in undergraduate engineering courses and also uncovered new questions about how to measure and monitor students' abilities to transfer knowledge to new situations.
